byline.contributor: Chau Doan contributed reporting from Tam Hung Commune. Kiki Zhao contributed research from Beijing.

abstract: Pledges made by China to cut growth of its greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 are undercut by large number of coal-fired power plants that are being built by Chinese companies, backed by state loans, across developing world; review of public records show at least 92 coal-fired plants will have been built or formally planned by Chinese companies since 2010.
lead_paragraph: Chinese banks and firms have built or are in contracts to build at least 92 coal-fired power plants in 27 countries, undermining efforts on climate change.

headline.main: China’s Emissions Pledges Are Undercut by Boom in Coal Projects Abroad
headline.print_headline: China’s Emissions Pledges Are Undercut by a Boom in Coal Projects Abroad

snippet: Chinese banks and firms have built or are in contracts to build at least 92 coal-fired power plants in 27 countries, undermining efforts on climate change.

keywords.value: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
keywords.name: glocations
